Posts.Content: Best of luck on a good path report & PSA. My husband had his surgery 1/29 and just had his PSA come back "negligible" which is good for a first score--down from a pre-surgery PSA of 9. Wishing you good news and continued good progress!!
Posts.Title: Liftoff!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Same for you & your husband, North! Thanks, Highlander
Posts.Title: Liftoff!

Posts.Title: Liftoff!

Posts.Content: The doctor's visit went well--he was very thorough and walked us through all the treatment options, including the ones that aren't appropriate for my husband's situation. He answered every question thoroughly and even gave us a copy of Dr. Walsh's book. His recommendation is robotic surgery and said my husband could wait until after the holidays to have it done. I have a few numbers that I hope will be useful in getting input from the group: PSA: 9 Biopsy: positive; two nodules, one on each side Gleason: 7 (3+4) Grade: T2C 11 out of 12 cores positive No evidence of perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension. ETA: added info Here's the breakdown of cores: (L) Positive 6 (3+3) <5% (K) Positive 6(3+3) 25% (J) Positive 6(3+3) 40% (I) Benign (H) Positive 6(3+3) 10% (G) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (C) Positive 7 (3+4) 45% (B) Positive 7 (3+4) 95% (A) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (F) Positive 6 (3+3) 10% (E) Positive 7 (3+4) 85% (D) Positive 7 (3+4) 90% Thanks in advance for your help.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter You should try to get the full biopsy report and read it. There should be more information on the report. For example, the size of his prostate, the detail of the 11 positive cores (e.g., % cancer, Gx+y for each core), whether there are indications of seminal vesicle involvement, whether there are EPE (extraprostatic extension) etc. It maybe counter intuitive but a large number of positive cores in this case is good news as it is consistent with a PSA of 9 and so hopefully cancer is organ confined. If you look at my case, I had a PSA of 10.7 but only 1 core <5% positive. I worried my cancer was systemic but fortunately post op they found lots of cancer all over but within the prostate which explained the PSA of 10.7. Good luck. I have the report. Here's the breakdown of cores: (L) Positive 6 (3+3) <5% (K) Positive 6(3+3) 25% (J) Positive 6(3+3) 40% (I) Benign (H) Positive 6(3+3) 10% (G) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (C) Positive 7 (3+4) 45% (B) Positive 7 (3+4) 95% (A) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (F) Positive 6 (3+3) 10% (E) Positive 7 (3+4) 85% (D) Positive 7 (3+4) 90% Given the involvement of 11 out of 12 cores with 3 cores at 95%, it would seem surgery is the only way to go. Right?
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla I'm sorry to hear that you and your husband have joined our club, but you are in good hands with the folks here. I think before most folks can really provide helpful insight, we need a little more information on the biobsy (e.g., # of positive cores and Gleason score on those cores). Also his PSA history would be helpful. Getting a second opinion on the biopsy will probably be helpful and usually recommended by most folks here. You can read up on Staging here. This is a decent link with info and questions. Others will chime in with their thoughts. Good luck! Thank you for the links, which I'll check out. I will post the biopsy details after seeing the doctor on Thursday. As for his PSA progression, the last time he had a blood workup was in 2010 and the PSA was in the normal range. In 9/14 it was 9 and on re-test it was 8.9.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi there -- and welcome to the forum. I'm sorry to hear of your husband's diagnosis. Wishing you the best during Thursday's appointment. As has been noted, getting a second opinion on the biopsy slides is a very good idea. If he has "intermediate" risk, it would mean his Gleason score is 7. Higher risk cases would mean Gleason scores of 8, 9 or 10. You will want to ask the doctor if his Gleason 7 is a 3+4 or a 4+3 because there can be a difference. "Low" risk prostate cancer is anything Gleason 6 (3+3) or lower. If a Gleason score of 7 is a 3+4, it means that the lower Gleason grade of 3 (the first number listed) is the dominant type of cancer cell found in that particular biopsy core. The second number, 4, represents the minority of Gleason grade cells in that core. Thus, a Gleason 3+4 often behaves more like the low risk Gleason 3+3, so you'll want to know if that is the the type he has. Even a 4+3, however, can be cured if it is still confined to the prostate. This leads to another question -- the doctor should also discuss the staging of the disease, as predicted by the biopsy report. If it is stage 1 or 2, it is still confined to the prostate and hence easier to cure. If the urologist recommends surgery, that would mean that he does expect it to be curable. If you consider surgery, make sure that the urologist has performed at least 300-400 open or robotic operations. That is critical because there is a long learning curve to achieve complete competence. You would also want to consult with a highly experienced radiation oncologist to find out the good and bad of radiation as a primary treatment. I would also recommend, as we do with newly diagnosed couples, that you both read the 3rd edition of Dr. Pat Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer." Hang in there and see what the doctor says on Thursday. In the meantime, others here will be offering their experiences, thoughts & advice. Take care, Chuck Thanks for the info--I've jotted down all the questions you raised. My husband's urologist is Dr. Alex Philpott, who is part of the Urology Center in Colorado. Website says they've performed over 3,000 robotic surgeries since 2006. I suspect he's over the 300 mark, but we'll ask. I ordered the book & will post details on Thursday. Appreciate the good advice & support.

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: My husband (63) just learned today that his biopsy is positive for prostate cancer with an "intermediate risk." His PSA was 9 and two nodules (one of each side) were discovered during a DRE. He is otherwise healthy, no chronic issues, non-smoker, plays tennis 3 times a week and has no family history of this type of cancer. We are both stunned and the diagnosis is just sinking in. My husband has an appointment with his urologist on Thursday to get more details and discuss options and I'd like to be prepared with questions. In doing a little research and talking to friends whose husbands went through it, getting a 2nd opinion is paramount, I'm told. Memorial Sloan Kettering is recommended. Do you all agree? What questions should we ask the urologist? Should we also see an oncologist right now? Thanks in advance for your help.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

He answered every question thoroughly and even gave us a copy of Dr. Walsh's book. His recommendation is robotic surgery and said my husband could wait until after the holidays to have it done. I have a few numbers that I hope will be useful in getting input from the group: PSA: 9 Biopsy: positive; two nodules, one on each side Gleason: 7 (3+4) Grade: T2C 11 out of 12 cores positive No evidence of perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension. ETA: added info Here's the breakdown of cores: (L) Positive 6 (3+3) <5% (K) Positive 6(3+3) 25% (J) Positive 6(3+3) 40% (I) Benign (H) Positive 6(3+3) 10% (G) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (C) Positive 7 (3+4) 45% (B) Positive 7 (3+4) 95% (A) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (F) Positive 6 (3+3) 10% (E) Positive 7 (3+4) 85% (D) Positive 7 (3+4) 90% Thanks in advance for your help.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter You should try to get the full biopsy report and read it. There should be more information on the report. For example, the size of his prostate, the detail of the 11 positive cores (e.g., % cancer, Gx+y for each core), whether there are indications of seminal vesicle involvement, whether there are EPE (extraprostatic extension) etc. It maybe counter intuitive but a large number of positive cores in this case is good news as it is consistent with a PSA of 9 and so hopefully cancer is organ confined. If you look at my case, I had a PSA of 10.7 but only 1 core <5% positive. I worried my cancer was systemic but fortunately post op they found lots of cancer all over but within the prostate which explained the PSA of 10.7. Good luck. I have the report. Here's the breakdown of cores: (L) Positive 6 (3+3) <5% (K) Positive 6(3+3) 25% (J) Positive 6(3+3) 40% (I) Benign (H) Positive 6(3+3) 10% (G) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (C) Positive 7 (3+4) 45% (B) Positive 7 (3+4) 95% (A) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (F) Positive 6 (3+3) 10% (E) Positive 7 (3+4) 85% (D) Positive 7 (3+4) 90% Given the involvement of 11 out of 12 cores with 3 cores at 95%, it would seem surgery is the only way to go. Right?
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla I'm sorry to hear that you and your husband have joined our club, but you are in good hands with the folks here. I think before most folks can really provide helpful insight, we need a little more information on the biobsy (e.g., # of positive cores and Gleason score on those cores). Also his PSA history would be helpful. Getting a second opinion on the biopsy will probably be helpful and usually recommended by most folks here. You can read up on Staging here. This is a decent link with info and questions. Others will chime in with their thoughts. Good luck! Thank you for the links, which I'll check out. I will post the biopsy details after seeing the doctor on Thursday. As for his PSA progression, the last time he had a blood workup was in 2010 and the PSA was in the normal range. In 9/14 it was 9 and on re-test it was 8.9.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi there -- and welcome to the forum. I'm sorry to hear of your husband's diagnosis. Wishing you the best during Thursday's appointment. As has been noted, getting a second opinion on the biopsy slides is a very good idea. If he has "intermediate" risk, it would mean his Gleason score is 7. Higher risk cases would mean Gleason scores of 8, 9 or 10. You will want to ask the doctor if his Gleason 7 is a 3+4 or a 4+3 because there can be a difference. "Low" risk prostate cancer is anything Gleason 6 (3+3) or lower. If a Gleason score of 7 is a 3+4, it means that the lower Gleason grade of 3 (the first number listed) is the dominant type of cancer cell found in that particular biopsy core. The second number, 4, represents the minority of Gleason grade cells in that core. Thus, a Gleason 3+4 often behaves more like the low risk Gleason 3+3, so you'll want to know if that is the the type he has. Even a 4+3, however, can be cured if it is still confined to the prostate. This leads to another question -- the doctor should also discuss the staging of the disease, as predicted by the biopsy report. If it is stage 1 or 2, it is still confined to the prostate and hence easier to cure. If the urologist recommends surgery, that would mean that he does expect it to be curable. If you consider surgery, make sure that the urologist has performed at least 300-400 open or robotic operations. That is critical because there is a long learning curve to achieve complete competence. You would also want to consult with a highly experienced radiation oncologist to find out the good and bad of radiation as a primary treatment. I would also recommend, as we do with newly diagnosed couples, that you both read the 3rd edition of Dr. Pat Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer." Hang in there and see what the doctor says on Thursday. In the meantime, others here will be offering their experiences, thoughts & advice. Take care, Chuck Thanks for the info--I've jotted down all the questions you raised. My husband's urologist is Dr. Alex Philpott, who is part of the Urology Center in Colorado. Website says they've performed over 3,000 robotic surgeries since 2006. I suspect he's over the 300 mark, but we'll ask. I ordered the book & will post details on Thursday. Appreciate the good advice & support.
Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: The doctor's visit went well--he was very thorough and walked us through all the treatment options, including the ones that aren't appropriate for my husband's situation. He answered every question thoroughly and even gave us a copy of Dr. Walsh's book. His recommendation is robotic surgery and said my husband could wait until after the holidays to have it done. I have a few numbers that I hope will be useful in getting input from the group: PSA: 9 Biopsy: positive; two nodules, one on each side Gleason: 7 (3+4) Grade: T2C 11 out of 12 cores positive No evidence of perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension. ETA: added info Here's the breakdown of cores: (L) Positive 6 (3+3) <5% (K) Positive 6(3+3) 25% (J) Positive 6(3+3) 40% (I) Benign (H) Positive 6(3+3) 10% (G) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (C) Positive 7 (3+4) 45% (B) Positive 7 (3+4) 95% (A) Positive 6 (3+3) 95% (F) Positive 6 (3+3) 10% (E) Positive 7 (3+4) 85% (D) Positive 7 (3+4) 90% Thanks in advance for your help.

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: My husband had DaVinci surgery on 1/29 and had almost no blood in his urine, except the first night post-surgery. He's been feeling so good, that he's back to walking our dogs, resumed work (at home) and going out for dinner, etc. Last night, he noticed what he sees is an alarming amount of blood in his urine. He's calling his doctor this morning, but I thought I'd check in here to see if you guys have experienced this or have an idea what may be causing it? Many thanks in advance.
Posts.Title: Sudden Blood in Urine Post-Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I was told it could come and go for up to 6-8 weeks post surgery. But it shouldn't be dark red and constant. Mine was pink, just a few drops at beginning and end of stream for about 4 weeks. Now, at 6 weeks, I just get an occasional blood clot Probably nothing to worry about but good that you called the dr. Let us know what they said. Thanks, Pratoman. My husband is still waiting for a callback from the doc, but he says the blood flow varies. The color is always dark red, but sometimes the blood flow is constant & once or twice it happened at the beginning and end. He's concerned he did too much & messed up internal stitches. This blood flow came on suddenly. I'll report back after we hear from the doc.
Posts.Title: Sudden Blood in Urine Post-Surgery

Posts.Content: I just wanted to report back on the bleeding issue...My husband's bleeding stopped within a few days once he was less active. He was walking the dogs, shoveling heavy snow, etc. and his body wasn't ready. It was just too soon post-surgery. He just had his first PSA blood test and it came back "negligible" and he got the OK from the doc to play tennis, which he did last Saturday! So, we are all very happy & relieved. Hoping for continued zero PSAs. He still has some incontinence when he walks, but he's doing his Kegels! How long does it take to resolve, or is that an individual thing?
